title: Michael Cheika bites back at Eddie Jones before Rugby World Cup quarters
text:
The old Randwick rivalry has reignited between Michael Cheika and Eddie Jones, laying the foundation of another spicy lead-up to an Australia-England quarter-final showdown at the Rugby World Cup.

The two nations will almost certainly meet in a quarter-final in Oita on Saturday next week, unless the unthinkable happens and Uruguay topple Wales in the final pool D match on Sunday. A Uruguay win would leave Australia on top of the group and facing France in the quarters.

Australia playmakers offer selection posers for likely England quarter-final | Bret Harris Read more

Cheika has clearly decided England are in his sights, speaking freely about a team they’ve lost to in six successive meetings, with most of those by wide margins.

Ex-Wallabies coach Jones, who loves pre-match banter as much as his counterpart, had issued a verbal prod to Australia this week. After his team’s scheduled match against France was cancelled by Rugby World Cup officials over typhoon safety fears, Jones said his team would benefit from a two-week break in comparison to the Wallabies, who were pushed hard by rugged Georgia on Friday.

Cheika said all his former teammate at Sydney club Randwick had done was heap pressure onto himself.

England cancellation has cost me a weekend in Japan and the World Cup its surprise factor Read more

“Well, I saw he was saying that that (cancellation) would be an advantage and the ’typhoon gods’ were smiling on him,” Cheika said “They’ve had the best preparation according to the coach so they’d better go out there and win. We’ll see how we go.”

Cheika dismissed talk England should be clear favourites, preferring to ignore the underdog discussion entirely.

England’s fallow weekend is not the ideal preparation it may seem | Robert Kitson Read more

“Mate, I don’t know the relevance of it,” he said. “The only relevance is Saturday. It doesn’t matter, all the different things, who’s had a week off, who’s had a week on, who’s been resting, who hasn’t.”

Cheika was quizzed on whether the clash with the forward-based Georgia was the ideal preparation for an England side who also base their game around a robust pack. While Cheika conceded it wasn’t because the teams are too different, he said the trench warfare nature of the match at a wet and wild Ecopa Stadium in Shizuoka was ideal for his players.

“The hit-out was good, just having to dig in and work hard, get up off the ground, get into some tough stuff,” he said. “That’s how we wanted the game to go, we wanted to work like that.”
description: The old Randwick rivalry has reignited between Michael Cheika and Eddie Jones, laying the foundation of a spicy lead-up to a probable Australia-England showdown at the Rugby World Cup
